timeline.bodyText: Realize it's the same as the previous pattern so optional update, we should probably set this to an unmodifaibleSet in the constructor instead of passing a mutable object around?
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: This is only used within a very narrow context where (in the Datadog codebase, at least) we will not mutate the set once it's built, making the unmodifiable wrapper a pointless cost. If we wanted to present a view of this set to untrusted callers, we would have wrapped it.
replies.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: Note that in this fork, you're not actually using the set at all, so I recommend just removing it and saving a bit of space.
replies.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: Just curious, is it possible for this class to be accessed from multiple threads? I wonder how many, if there are a lot of copies of this buffer, it's unfortunate they all get stuck in memory after classloading is done sort of lean towards not using a threadlocal for it, string seems pretty small.
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText:
it will come here from any thread that triggers class loading for AgentClassLoader, so likely not too many different threads, as the various instrumentation classes will only be loaded the first time they are used
we could do ThreadLocal<WeakReference<StringBuilder>>, but that wouldn't get it out of the ThreadLocal map, which is also nice to reduce collisions
so maybe WeakReference<ThreadLocal<StringBuilder>>?
(i'm also ok with no change here)
@richardstartin wdyt?
replies.author: trask

replies.bodyText:
I sort of lean towards not using the threadlocal optimization for these small strings and let it all be garbage that can be collected, over the complexity of weak references, since I suspect this is a tiny part of the optimization in the attached PR.
But if we're only leaking a few hundred bytes it's not so bad either.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: @trask actually this was an insurance policy against there ever being more than one thread accessing the variable. We haven't seen any negative consequences in our benchmarks, but I think it's a question of "take it or leave it" - if it doesn't look right to you, please just change it.
replies.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: This is because this is a performance optimization, not for correctness, I'm presuming
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText:
Reference assignment is atomic so this cannot lead to inconsistency.
If some other thread doesn't see the write, they just see another instance or null, and may or may not do extra work.
replies.author: richardstartin
anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: If I understand correctly, all these changes to this class are performance optimisations, no? Is there any benchmark or, even better, a real use-case, which demonstrate the benefit of this?
timeline.author: iNikem

timeline.bodyText: I would love to see some explanations, why these class loaders in particular are listed.
timeline.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText: this was not changed in this PR, but class loaders are listed in here so that java-classloader instrumentation will not be skipped. the way these are caught and added here is that AgentTestRunner does not use AdditionalLibraryIgnoresMatcher, and then it validates that there are no classes that were instrumented that would have been skipped by AdditionalLibraryIgnoresMatcher, and so the test fails, and then you add suppress the class from being skipped in here
replies.author: trask

timeline.bodyText: What is the motivation of this optimisation?
timeline.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText: I suggest you review the original PR.
replies.author: tylerbenson

timeline.bodyText: Why extract this to a field? It is still used only inside one method, no?
timeline.author: iNikem

timeline.bodyText: This attribute is certainly not from semantic convention. Why should we want this into Otel?
timeline.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText:
we (currently at least) capture lots of span attributes that are not defined by semantic conventions
maybe better if we prefixed this, e.g. kafka.tombstone, so it doesn't look like a semantic attribute?
replies.author: trask

replies.bodyText: "We are already doing strange things, let us do more strange things" is not exactly good reason :) We already have unanswered questions "why do we have this attribute here", such as dispatcher.target or servlet.origin. I am hesitant to add more.
replies.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText: i created #602 to track and make decision about this
replies.author: trask

timeline.bodyText: This will benefit from documentation. This is a good place to document how different instrumentation coordinate with each other and for what purpose.
timeline.author: iNikem
